text: Warehouse district, near the river... A statue of a Confederate soldier stands in the shadows, his rifle held high and proud. Beyond, a Civil War cannon points out from the darkness.
bright and blinding from down the street, they pass over statue and find a sign: "Louisiana National Guard"...The ear slowly glides into the Armory parking lot.
as a pick-up truck down-shifts. From the opposite end of the street another vehicle approaches, followed by more headlights...and more headlights...and more again. cur TO:

Two basketball hoops. Framed photos of Generals and milit leaders. An American flag.crossed with the state banner o Louisiana...Spelled out in bold letters across the far wa "This is the Home of the. Best Infantry Company in the Wo

Some sit or lie on the cement, others lean: against the b wall, still others fueling up on coffee and donuts. U.S, Army fatigues everywhere; boots, bayonets, buttpacks, amm pouches, canteens hanging from pistol belts, steel pot he with camouflage nets... (CONTINUED)
A whistle blows.
Fall int Grudgingly, the men start to assemble, picking up their duffle bags and forming lines. Again the whistle blows.
Come on, fall in!
Four platoons, 110 men standing alongside their duffles. The First Sergeant moves before them and begins shouting names from a clipboard. Each man answers with a half- hearted "yeah" or "yo".

Marian...Masterson\..Mayhew... Maxvill...Meadows...Merritt... Middlebrook... These are the weekend warriors. Some having signed on years ago to duck the draft, some of them just like being in the club, the others. in for the money each month and the prospect of a pension. cur To:
Now at parade rest. A man appears at the far doorway.
Company!
Platoon!
Aten-Hut! (CONTINUED)
C& The Guardsmen come to attention as Captain Underwood e and exchanges a snappy salute with the First Sergeant. .
Company all present or accounted for, sir.
Take your post, Sergeant.
Late forties. Lean and mean. Hair cut yesterday. Boots glistening, fatigues starched. His voice crisp, sharp. Complete command.
At ease. The Company relaxes. Men shift weight, scratch.

Platoon sergeants. After your men draw their weapons you'll be in the trucks ready to move out at 0500. There is the possibility some battalion brass will be coming down to observe you people...Please for once in your life could you try to look like soldiers...
Platoon!
Aten-Hut! The Company snaps to attention.
Black; 25 years old, a lineman for Louisiana Bell Telepho His mental agility belies his 11th grade education. Marri Sa (CONTINUED)
two children, a third on the way. As he stands at attenti he notices a lone figure slowly making his way across the Armory.
Here he is, pride of the regiment. All eyes target on:

handsome, with the look of youth that comes from living the soft life. His hair flops over his forehead,. coverin a portion of his glasses. His boots need a shine, his uniform a pressing. Not a sad sack, but he is spoiled Southern. His steel helmet is tied to the duffle bag and clangs out as he drags it across the cement floor. As he passes the Captain, Atwater casually flicks a salute in the officer's general direction.
Captain.
You're late, soldier. To the snickering of the men and the stare of the Captain Atwater joins Ist ‘Squad, 2nd Platoon. Stands in line nex to Wilson.
Did I miss sick call?
standing next to Wilson on the other side. -Wears a weddi ring. Thirty years old. A Chemical Engineer transferred down from New Jersey two months ago by Texaco. Not too thrilled about being here.
Platoon leaders, move ‘em out.
being issued their rifles, checking their equipment, helping each other with their packs, loading gear into the trucks...the vehicles engines kick over, headlights . go on. ;

A fortunate few sit on the folding benches along the side the others lying on the floor among their duffle bags and rifles...outside a young Lieutenant passes by, decides to look in for a regulation growl.
You men comfortable?
Yes sir!
Can't hear you! They roar back.
Good. The Lieutenant moves briskly on.
Why is everybody always yelling around here? He speaks with the voice of a man with a terrific hangove
A roaring line of Jeeps and trucks snorting black exhaust headlights sweeping past the Armory.
The last vehicle of the ten truck convoy shelters the men of the 2nd platoon; 40 of them taking the bumps, settling down, trying either to get comfortable or, even a better idea, to get some sleep.
Big and solid. Red of neck. Likes a good time. Nineteen years old. He pulls a six pack of Dixie beer out of his duffle bag and offers it around after popping one open for himself.
Anybody for a brew? His pal Masterson makes the automatic reach. As does Atwater.
Hair of the dog.

Late 20's. Works in the oil fields. Completed his three years regular Army and is in the Guard because he likes it. Drives a pick-up, wears a drooping moustache and sideburns...A life model for Longbrake.
Christ. Even the cows ain't up.
Early 20's. Black, Street smart. Happy, as long as he's high, which is almost always. Longbrake Masterson
We there yet?
Hey, Tyrone. You ready for this?
Shit, I been getting ready all week on reds and whites...blues even. tosses out a few more beers. ATWATER . Where we spending the weekend?
Atchaflaya basin. Don't you ever listen up Atwater?
Why in Christ they taking us to the bonnies for?
Don't ask me. Hey Masterson, why in Christ are they taking us to the boonies for? looks back at Wilson with mild irritation.
Cause.
Oh I see. 'Long as you put it that way. Atwater takes a long drink of beer.
The convoy rolls through the suburbs of Baton Rouge; all quiet among the rows of houses beyond the rumbling column khaki colored vehicles.
Most of the 2nd Platoon now sound asleep, oblivious to th first rays of sunlight. A slow stretching move by one of the uniformed men...

Biggest of them all. And all of it's muscle. Teaches nint grade history and is also the varsity line coach at Lafay Union High School. He's not one to be taken lightly... Unfortunately he doesn't take himself lightly either, see cl himself as a scholar-athlete and is clearly a man who the sound of his own voice.
Trust you brought your portable air conditioner, Atwater.
And refrigerator.
Atwater's the only man in the history of the Guard that brings satin sheets to summer camp.
What you all doin' in the truck with us anyway, Atwater? Why ain't you ridin' down on a polo pony?
Listen, my polo pony wouldn't associate with you guys.
lights a cigarette and closes his eyes, trying to block o the bullshit. cur TO:

Now moving along the Interstate highway. Morning breaking on a sharp, clear day...it's going to be a hot one...A little girl at a Gas Station waves as the trucks pass. Th Guardsmen give her the finger.
Three men, Squad Leader Taylor, next to him a Sergeant fr the 2nd Squad and...

Behind the wheel. His sleeves are pushed up and his right forearm has a tatoo of a pirate skull. He dropped out of high school to join the Army and fight in Nam, but they stopped the war. Pissed him off. Still has ideas though. ' Lives alone, keeps two cats. Subscribes to "Soldier of Fortune",
Know what I hear? That they're looking for professionals in Africa.
Whores?
Mercenaries. In Mexico and Latin America too.. Pays $1300 a month plus transportation. (CONTINUED)
a
Man could retire.
I read about it. They're lookin' all the time. :
Two tours in Viet Nam. Decorated. Knows how to play the game. Going for his twenty year pension, already has nine in...The men of the 2nd Platoon all respect him; a good m to have on your side.
They want combat soldiers, Norman. Not typists.
The trucks are moving laboriously down a four lane highwa In the distance an isolated shopping center site stands h constructed.
Longbrake looks across at the half-asleep Wilson.
Hey, Clitoris. Wilson cuts him off cold.
Cleotis.
Yeah. When we get down in them swamps, be sure you watch out for those snakes. (CONTINUED)
I'll watch for them. I just don't want them watchin' for me.
Someone has finally said something that interests him...o at least something that he thinks he ought to know about.
What kind of snakes?
Moccasins. Copperheads.
One a them bites you, you bend over, stick your head between your knees and kiss your ass goodbye.
quietly reaches into his pocket and pulls out a box of 5- ammunition. Without drawing attention from the others, snaps a shell into the chamber of his M-16.
When I was training in Fort Benning, our instructor got bit right here by a coral snake. He extends his right arm.
He put his hand on a log, took his machette, and cut his hand right off, I swear to God. Groans and smiles; nobody believes him. (CONTINUED)
Masterson leans out over the tailgate of the truck, level his M-16 at the approaching supermarket construction site and sends a bullet into a huge plate glass window, a quar of a mile beyond.
The window shatters and falls.
A proud smile shines out from under Masterson's moustache some of the boys think this is the funniest thing they've ever seen.
I ain't worried about snakes. He reaches into his shirt and displays the box of live ammunition.
Shit, you sonofabitch. Why didn't you tell me you brought real ammo? A violent sway from the lurching vehicle.
The truck pulling over hard to the right, onto the should of the road.
Braking sounds from the heavy vehicle...The small window separating the truck bed from the cab is snapped open.
Allright, what the fuck was that? (CONTINUED)
Backfire.
Norman? |
Yeah? '
Fuck you. |
Why don't you get these sons of bitches tuned up, Norman. | Taylor's head appears at the window.
Whatever the hell's going on back there, knock it off... The Guardsmen go quiet. A long moment.
Okay, Norman let's go. The window again snaps up...a moment later the truck lurc into gear.
Wide smile. He got away with it.
His stoical expression doesn't quite mask his contempt. Atwater is the only one quick enough to notice. He grins across to Calvelli.
Yeah, we ain't smart, but we sure have fun.
The Convoy leisurely moving down the business section; a shopkeeper is opening his General Store as the trucks rol past...the Old Man gets pelted with empty beer cans. cur TO:
Knocked out, sweaty, quiet as they bounce along. Then, finally, the truck grinds to a slow halt.
We stopped.
You're right up there with the latest news, aren't ya. Outside the truck a raspy male voice penetrates the morni air.
Alright! Let's go in there! Outta the truck! Slowly the men start dropping out over the tailgate. They fall and trip, getting hit with helmets, rifles, duffle b

Atwater, Calvelli, Youngblood, Smith, Longbrake, Masterso Wilson forming a loose rank and making an unhurried attem to get organized...They look across at the unfamiliar ter ‘THEIR POV: THE BAYOU Across a high levee...Marshes stretch to the horizon line Thin pines rise out of the misty swamps; the trees are bearded with moss but their branches are dead and bare.

Still near their truck; around them the bivouac area is jumping with activity as Guardsmen start digging trenches for latrines, laying wire, pitching tents. A Lieutenant i barking orders from the perimeter of the clearing.
Sergeant! Get your men digging in...I don't want to see you. I£ I can see you, the enemy can see you...Set up your security. He notices the men of the Ist Squad.
Hey you meatballs! What the hell do you think you're doing there... Why aren't you with your platoon?
Special detail, sir.
What kind of detail?
With the truck. Make sure it's not captured, Sir.
Get over with your unit. Now! Load and lock down. They slowly move off. The Lieutenant turns his back; Wils uses this opportunity to give him a quick finger.
Sitting in the shade, slowly feeding blanks into the maga clips. Longbrake is loading the big M-60 Machine Gun, amm belts draped around his neck. (CONTINUED)
Lord, this sun can broil a man alive.
Hey Calvelli, bet you thought all the Louisiana Guard did was beat up on college kids and tear | gas niggers. The kind of comment that gives Wilson an opening.

Please mistah guardsman, no moah canisters. Don't let that shepherd , | dog loose on me. Longbrake wants to have some fun at the new man's expense as well; with studied casualness he points the big M-60 a Calvelli.
ji Yeah, I remember seeing you guys on television, and say, pal... (pushes machine gun barrel away) don't be pointing that thing at me.
Only blanks.

I don't care if it's hundred dollar bills, don't point it at me. Edgy silence, long looks between the two men. Atwater dec to break the tension, only right since he was the one tha first got the ball rolling.
Longbrake, don't you be picking on our new man. Got to be polite to them foreign boys.
(CONTINUED)
You from New York?
New Jersey.
Same difference.
Yeah. Right. Norman runs up from across the clearing.
Alright, let's hurry it up. Don't just sit there. Soon as you're finished, go over with the rest of the platoon and get squared away.
Yes, Norman. — LONGBRAKE Fuck you, Norman.
Too hot to be hurryin'. Norman waits impatiently while the Squad slowly pick them selves up.
Suppose. you're used to a little more serious soldiering back in | New Jersey.
Yeah, we had things organized. The only thing we did was watch the ball games on tee vee, shoot dice, and sleep. (CONTINUED)
They get up and start moving, again looking off at the ba and the swamps beyond. Youngblood feels that the sight ca for his personal comment.
The primordial swamp. That's where it all started, gentlemen. Right in there.
That's real interesting, Coach.
I know that you have trouble dealing with an abstract idea, Atwater. Atwater walks over near Calvelli, away from the main grou
Gonna be a long fucking weekend if I have to listen to this shit.
moving slowly across the clearing; Taylor joins them, dra them into a circle. They light cigarettes, sit on their hélmets.
I got good news and bad news. Bad news is there is no good news. We're going on an over- night recon patrol. Massive groans.
Okay, quit your bitching and listen up to Sgt. Taylor. (CONTINUED)
Fuck you, Norman.
That's enough of that...Alpha team will be recon. Bravo team security...Calvelli you're with Bravo. Looks over his men.

Levee up this way is our objective, rendezvous point is outside New Iberia. We're going to travel in overwatch and movement in file formation with maximum use of concealment...Smith, you with us? Smith obviously isn't.
Sure am Sergeant. I'm really up for this one.
Good, cause you're going to be my pace man. Big laugh from the boys. They know a good joke when they hear one.
Masterson'1l be: point...We're talking about 38 kilometers so make sure you fill your canteens at the water buffalo.
Any liquor stores open? Taylor ignores Atwater. (CONTINUED)
Every member pitches in and pulls their weight. I don't want any- body dogging it out there. You're all buddies, counting and depending on each other. Everybody does their job. Turns away.

filling their canteens from the spigots on the tanker tru fixing their butt packs, adjusting straps, ponchos...Wils is pulling the big P.R.C. two-way communicator into place on his back, then positions the pads to keep it from cutt into his shoulders.
We sure get all the good details.
This will be good exercise for you. Put a little muscle in your pants. Youngblood enjoys his own feeble joke.
That's the last thing I need, Coach. Unless you want to take care of it.
Anything you like, Longbrake. Speaking for myself I prefer women.
Big chance we got of that. (CONTINUED)
® ATWATER Life's full of surprises, son.
What does that mean? Atwater's got their full attention. He plays the moment, pausing, smiling.

I have arranged for a little treat for the weekend, boys. Six whores de combat presently awaiting our assault...I'm sure they'll fuck us in a more inter- esting way than the National Guard of the state of Louisiana has.
You're not kidding, are you?
a I never joke about women.
I haven't been laid in six hours. I'm ready.
How they gonna meet us?
Yeah, where are they?

Holed up, waiting my call. (he moves around to Wilson, puts his arm around the big P.R.C. radio) That responsibility for contact rests on my old buddy Wilson, and his trusty walkie talkie. (CONTINUED)
You got one for me?
Me? You mean us, don't you brother? Pause.

Now boys remember, the purpose of the National Guard is to keep you darker brothers away from decent Southern women... But in the spirit of the New South I have made full arrange- ments. Smiles all around. And a few cheers.
Atwater, you ain't all bad. They begin moving away from the water buffalo.

They are now nine combat ready men, walking in file. Swea begins to seep through their fatigues. Twigs and pieces o bush now grow from their steel helmets. Sgt. Taylor has field glasses, amp, flashlight and compass. Wilson is alo side...Longbrake packs the big M-60 machine gun, ammo bel draped around his neck. All the rest have M-16 rifles... The Squad moves forward, walking up and over the levee to the bayou.
When I was a kid, people used to live all up and down these bayous. (CONTINUED)
Government cleared them out.
Must of been tough leaving a real paradise like this. The Squad clears the crest of the levee. At the fringe of the bayou they slowly pull up, look off at the horizon.
Norman, shape them up and test fire. This is as good a place as any. Norman whirls and begins shouting; this is the kind of assignment he takes very seriously.
Squad. Forma line. Every rifleman 20 feet apart! .
Hey, Norman?
Yeah, what is it Longbrake?

Fuck you. The men spread out, open their ammo pouches, slap the mag zines into the breeches of their M-16's, slide the bolts and commence firing. Atwater takes advantage of this mome to aim and fire at Wilson...
Don't do that, mother fucker. Longbrake's M-60 machine gun spits out a few blank shells Then all goes quiet once more.
Masterson, we want to move out on a heading of zero six five. (CONTINUED)
Yo. He moves off a confident experienced soldier, qualities h shares only with Taylor among the other members of the Br team.
moving off into the swamp following thirty yards behind Masterson's point. The quality of the moment so excites Atwater that he brea into song:
Over hill, Over dale, As we hit the dusty trail... The spirit is infectious; the entire Squad save Taylor, Norman and Calvelli join in.
And those caissons keep rolling along. It's hi hi hee In the field artillery And those caissons go rolling... Some members of the Bravo Team substitute the words "fuck for caissons. cut To:

Hot, humid, dense foliage climbing alongside a small bayo twenty yards wide. The muddy water is still and tepid, punctuated only by floating water vegetation. Birds call, the buzz of insects, a bull frog belches.
His camouflage blends him into the foliage. He looks righ then left, up the bayou, swings his rifle onto his should and takes a reading.
in palm of right hand. His left hand shields the dial fro the blazing sun.

snaps the compass closed, tucks it away, wipes the sweat his face and takes a long swig from his canteen. He gives arm and hand signal to those behind, holds his rifle read and wades across the bayou.
They come out of the growth, in file, as Taylor waits for them. Masterson visible across the shallow body of water beyond.
Where the fuck are you guys taking us?
is almost at the opposite bank when he stumbles...stops, throws his rifle sling over his shoulder freeing his hand Masterson begins grappling with some fish netting that encases his feet.
can see Masterson's difficulty from thirty yards back. Ge (CONTINUED)
What the hell is it? .
now cutting the net with his bayonet, tearing it loose fr the stream bed...
Nothing. Just some God damn drag line net. Frees himself and moves on.
approaches the water's edge, not happy with his immediate prospects. ar] Christ.
Go ahead and cross the God damn thing, don't just stand there looking at it.
I can't go in there, I've got a terminal hangover.
Water will take care of it real nice.
I think I should go back. No kidding. I'm serious. Wilson pretends to send a radio message on his P.R.C. (CONTINUED)
Echo 7-1, request helicopter med-evac, top priority terminal hangover. Read me, roger and over.
Take up your position Atwater. Atwater crosses, sloshing through the calf-deep bayou, adjusting his backpack as he goes. Smith next approaches the water's edge...
Smith, how you doin' with the pace?
Great. 461 meters...more or less. Very large smile from Taylor; he's not depending on anyon else for direction or distance.
Right...Couldn't make it without you, Tyrone. Both men cross with Wilson.

The ist Squad eating C rations; they sit a few feet apart in the mossy shade of a cypress tree. Smith lifts one of the metal containers and for inexplicable reasons becomes engrossed reading the catalog of contents.
Meal. Combat individual. Pork, sliced and cooked...crackers, peanut butter, dried prunes...
Wilson and Atwater huddled over the P.R.C.
(presses the recharge button) * 7-1, 7-1, this is 7-8, over.
7-8, this is 7-1.
Change in orders necessitates you make contact with advance party. Urgent. Move Operation Southern Belle to coordinates 07-035.
We copy. 07-035.
Battle position installations set for 2200 hours.
2200 hours. Support troops standing by. Over. He puts the phone back and smiles at Atwater; Smith has heard the transmission.
(big smile) Atwater, shittt...get them women.
What's the pace, Tyrone?
380, 455, 770. Whatever one gets us to those ladies the fastest. Norman comes back across the clearing. (CONTINUED)
Okay, off and on. Break time's over. Let's go, move it. Longbrake can't afford to miss his cue.
Fuck you, Norman. Atwater slowly rises.
Civilian in peace, soldier in war, I am the Guard.
Again on the move in close file; the still water churns a the weeds break as the Guardsmen go wading through. Thoug it is mid-day and the sun is blazing, there is an eerie darkness to all. ,
As the Squad comes moving through. Atwater and Wilson dod among the branches and undergrowth, trailed by Longbrake.
The whole package will cost you sixty one dollars a month, covers everything, house, life, wife and kids.
Man, I told you before I can't afford that. (CONTINUED)
Everybody right. 30.
A man in your line of work, climbing telephone poles all day, two kids, another in the oven, you can't afford hot to have full coverage.
Knock it off back there!
Ah, fuck you up there.
And keep those God damn helmets on!
D. Company. The dirty thirty.
D for douche bag.
Dork company.
Doonesbury. looks at Youngblood, he can never get anything
Doonesbury?
(counting his pace) 478, 479...Dickheads! 382, 383, 384...
Okay, knock it off. They walk a few yards in silence, then: (CONTINUED )
©) CALVELLI Jesus! Jesus Christ! He drops to the ground, slapping and pulling at his pants
It's on me. Shit! Something's on me! Sgt. Taylor is the first one to him. The others gather ro
Got a black widow on ya? Tarantula maybe? Longbrake just thinks it's funny as hell.
a an inch across and unfortunately deeply imbedded in Cal N calf.
Okay take it easy now. Hold still. Taylor has his zippo out and puts the flame to the tick's backside...after the insect has pulled back he scrapes it off Calvelli's leg with his pocket knife.
There. It's off.
It's still bleeding.
You want it to. The rest of the men begin itching and scratching. (CONTINUED )
You see that sucker?
If you pull it off, the head stays in and you die.
You don't die, Cretin. Your leg just gets infected.
Yeah. And rots off.
Who you calling a Cretin?
You. Youngblood's much too big to argue with; the men of Bravo Team, dork company begin to shoulder their packs and move out.
moving through swamp a few paces ahead of the rest of the Squad save Masterson's point. He studies the map a bit, t returns it to his breast pocket.
Smith, send up the pace.
(from behind) Huh?
Hey Lightning, Taylor wants the pace. (CONTINUED )
Pace? What pace you talkin bout? Oh, the pace. 635?
Tell him it's 635!
Wilson, inform Company we're crossing phase line Bob.
(into phone) Echo 7-1, this is Echo 7-8, do you copy?
Roger 7-8, go ahead.
Have crossed phase line Bob, over.
That's a roger 7-8, you have crossed phase line Bob.
Okey dokey smokey.
7-1, have received confirmation on Southern Belle. Advance party on manuevers anticipating small unit military penetration.
Wilson breaks into a big, big smile.
That is a roger. (CONTINUED)
What was all that about?
Damned if I know, I never can understand that man. He swats at a bug.
Damn mosquitos. Wilson turns, catches Atwater's eye and gives him a big s and the high sign. Atwater smiles, turns to Longbrake and nods. The word spreads, Operation Southern Belle is a go.
He makes his way and stops at the edge of a large bayou, the biggest yet seen, some sixty yards wide. The rest of the Squad trails behind...
as he catches sight of the large body of water.
Looks like they built a new ocean here.
I can't figure out where the hell we are. We should be right in here. (looks at his map) Now either this damn map is wrong or I can't find my way around the block. :
I kept right like you told me. (CONTINUED)
Yeah, I know...bayou's must of shifted.
Want me to raise Company?
No need for that. Long as we keep going North we'll be alright.
moving along the bank of the bayou.
Get those weapons off your shoulders.
Fuck you Norman. You carry this elephant gun! Gestures to his big M-60...it does in fact weight forty-f pounds.
Not so close together. Watch your positions.
He stops, looks ahead, further along the edge of the bayo
Hand-made dugouts, like big canoes, pulled up on high gro
Both have long poles used for pushing forward. In the she (CONT INUED )
of one of Masterson
Masterson 36.
the craft are four dead neutria (giant furry rats). whistles to the others.
Over here.
Who you. think they belong to?
Us.
No they don't. They belong to the indiginous personnel. Don't fuck around with them.
Think they float?
Hell, yes. They're pirogues. Cajuns back here use ‘em all the time.
They ain't using them now. turns to Taylor.
What say we take them down the bayou?
Yeah. I can deal with that. Way my back feels.
Don't forget. I have a very impor- tant hangover. (CONTINUED )
Hell, we might make New Iberia tonight.
Put them women under martial law.
What women you talking about?
Atwater's running ladies. Silence.
He's got some ladies meeting us.
Atwater?
It's all set...Noleen The Bayou Queen. And her court...Just a little something for morale.
Really? Doesn't seem to be happy with this news.
Youngblood comes forward.
++I don't think we should take the canoes. They're not ours.
That's right they're not ours... Now let's get in them. They move for the pirogues. (CONTINUED)
Hold on, fungo. Nobody gave you an order. They stop and look at Taylor.
A little R & R never hurts.
Part of being a soldier is learning to live off the land.
How bout it, Sergeant?
Well now boys, I just don't know. Pause.
What kind of foot soldier would take some beat up old boat? Pause.
We would.
You're right. Cheers. Whistles. They break for the pirogues.
Commandeer the swamp craft of indigenous personnel!
as they divide up, according to Taylor's orders. (CONTINUED)

Wilson, Masterson, Youngblood, Atwater with me. Rest of you with Norman...Just watch out you don't tip the damn things over, Norman, Calvelli, Smith and Longbrake get in the pirogue. Longbrake holding the M-60 in his lap.
The men squat down, Taylor has his map out.
Atwater, you take the pole.
Not me, Sarge. Let Youngblood do it. He's good at that stuff.
They are tricky and rock easily and almost tip, but the m keep their balance and both pirogues glide along, side by side, racing. The men are laughing and hollering.
He points back to the shore, laughs...
At this distance their features are unrecognizable, but t are big, dark and frightening men, in rubber hip boots.
Where'd they come from? Smith waves at them, uses a falsetto voice. (CONTINUED )
Hi, boys. Thanks for the boats.
(fruity) I think they want their boats back. Masterson gives them the finger.
Fuck em!
Taylor is yelling through cupped hands at the Cajuns.
We'll bring em back.
They only speak French.
staring...silent...ominous even at forty yards.
twenty yards from opposite bank.
Can anybody speak French?
Sure. (he yells) Voulez-vous fuck me!
Knock that shit off! Taylor yells and points to the shore.
We're bringing them back! The Cajuns watch them head farther across.
(to Cajuns) Just dropping them off.
They don't understand.
Dumb coonass bastards. From no place, Longbrake levels his machine gun at the Ca and opens fire.
Let em have it men! Take no prisoners!
dive for cover as the machine gun bursts out.

Longbrake! YOU ASSHOLE! Some members of the Squad think this is even funnier than when Masterson took a shot at the supermarket. Masterson snaps off a shot, as does Wilson, Smith and Atwater. Big laughs.
Knock that shit off! The Cajuns are no longer visible. (CONTINUED)
Norman! Get your men off and get that damn boat back! Now!
Right. Push for that shoreline, Smith. The sound of a single rifle shot.
What was that?
God they shot him dead!
shot straight through the head -- killed instantly.
drops his pole leaps back for Taylor.
No! The pirogue tips over from the shifting weight and Youngb lunging motion. ¢
They try to swim toward the near shore.
The radio and rifle on his back keep pulling him down. He bobs, slapping at the water, then goes under. He's fighti to get free of the radio straps, and not winning.
SATURDAY AFTERNOON °
Sees Wilson go under and tries to save him. Wilson is panicking, takes Atwater down with him.
Reaches Norman's pirogue and tries to climb on, tipping t pirogue over.
Sees Atwater and Wilson, and swims to help.
One of the radio straps are free. Wilson is still fightin
Leave him alone. I got him. Calvelli grabs Wilson from behind the neck. He slides the other strap off Wilson's shoulder and the radio sinks.

head_text.subj: THE SQUAD STAGGERING OUT OF THE BAYOU

text: Wet, scared, confused, they stumble, ducking behind trees
Hit it! Get down.
Take cover!
They shot him. They shot him!
Lonnie! Over here. (CONTINUED )
Do you see them? Where are they?
The dirty sons of bitches.
All is still. No Cajuns in sight.
Jesus Christ, what's happening?
Are they still shooting? Where are they?
Can't see them.
Where are they?
Keep down!
There's Atwater and them.
Taylor. We have to get Taylor.
Come on. Keeping low, they dart along, wade into the bayou and fis Taylor out.
Coughing up water, they collapse in the mud bank. (CONTINUED)
Atwater. Over here. Atwater, Wilson and Calvelli run toward the rest of the S and protective cover.
M-16 held ready, darting through the underbrush along the bayou shore. He peers across the water toward the far ban
No movement, no-one in sight.
hesitates for a moment, then turns back toward the interi

head_text.subj: DENSE UNDERBRUSH AWAY FROM THE WATER

text: Taylor's corpse has been laid out...The men kneel, gaping their dead squad leader. Masterson trots up.
No sign of them. ' Norman covers Taylor with a poncho, then starts going t his personal effects.
Where the hell's the map?
He was holding it, I remember. (CONTINUED)
The compass is broken.
How'd that happen?
I must of hit it on the side of the boat.
Shit! Youngblood? What the hell you tip us over for?
I didn't mean to.
And where's your weapon?
Lost it. Norman. looks around.
Atwater, where's yours?
With Wilson's.
Where's that?
In the water.
Well it's going to cost you. You're going to pay for losing them you know. $253.50.
Wilson. Where's the radio? (CONTINUED)
Pause. 47.
...With my rifle.
Jesus.
How much that gonna cost me?
You're supposed to be in charge of it! What the hell's the matter with you!
Hey, man. Kiss my ass.
Let's go get those fuckers.
Sure. All we have to do is swim sixty yards and then find them back in that forest.
We'll follow through with our mission. That's our responsi- bility. Authorities will be back here to deal with these bastards.
Those guys were just firing a warning shot to scare us.
They're doing a hell of a job.
Come on, let's haul ass. (CONTINUED )
You know something we don't.
We need some distance. Instead of us going after them they might decide to come after us.
Shit. There's only two of them.
Lot more than that. And they're all related.
What about Taylor?
Leave him.
No. We'll take him with us. He deserves that much.
I say we leave him. Unless you want to carry him...we can bury him here.
He's an American soldier. He's got the Bronze Star, Purple Heart, and Vietnam Service medal.
+.eSo what? The quicker we get out of here, the quicker they can come back for him.
Make's sense...Come on Norman, let's get moving.
God damn it we're not leaving him here. (CONTINUED)
Who says.
God damn it I got the stripe. I'm in charge and I don't want to hear any more about it.
The. men are soaked...sweating...Norman leading the way. the rear. Wilson and Youngblood carry the poncho stick stretcher. Masterson patrols the rear, alert for possible attack fro
Think Norman knows where he's going?
Eight to five against.
Let's knock off that negative, crap. He knows about the army, give him that much.
What I want to know is does he know the way home?
Longbrake you are one dumb son of a bitch, firing that machine gun.
Me? What about you! You shot at them!
Forget it. (CONTINUED )
Forget it, shit!
That's right, Longbrake. Who gave you the order to fire?
Fuck you, Norman.
It's not funny, asshole! Masterson calls up from the rear.
Hey, he wasn't the one that shot Taylor.
No, all you guys had a hand in that one. They trudge by.
Fog moving through the swamp in cloud-like patches. Buzzi insect sounds. The men of Bravo Team sit shivering in the ponchos by a small fire. Calvelli slaps at his face.
God damn bugs.
They're just gnats. (CONTINUED )
Sl.
Man y'oughta look at them fuckers under a microscope. They got teeth for miles.
I got em in my ears, up my nose and down my throat.
Maybe if you wouldn't talk so much they wouldn't get in.
Hell, Merc's wear short pants in Rhodesia. Think of that. Atwater non-plussed at Norman's illogic.
We'll keep that in mind. I'll = tell you something else to think about. We got a dead man here, and we got to find our way out.
I'm telling you after we get Taylor back to headquarters we should come back after these Cajun cocksuckers.
You guys handle it. I've had enough shooting to last me a while... Calvelli looks at Masterson.
You say these guys are Cajuns?
Yeah...fuckin' savages. Lay (CONTINUED)
What are you talking about? I went to some kind of Cajun luau when I first got here... Atwater can't believe what he's hearing.
Cajun luau?
I don't know what it was called... | It was some kind of party with ' crayfish and gumbo, all that shit.
Jambalaya.
Whatever...They didn't look like any kind of savages to me. The toughest it got was accordion music.
Cajuns in St. Charles or Lafayette are okay. The ones still living back here are a whole other story.
They're weird. Youngblood cuts loose in his most sonorous classroom tone
What he means is they've maintained the traditional Cajun culture. Really they're magnificent anachronisms.
Right. They even fuck their sisters. Even their grandmothers. This is too much for Longbrake. (CONTINUED)
Bullshit.
I ain't shittin' you. Swear to God.
Pause. What I want to know is will they fuck with us?
Goddamn right they will.
Why?
They don't like outsiders comin' in here.
If you knew all this, how come you stole the boats?
Hell I ain't afraid of 'em.
Terrific.
Maybe it's about time to divide up the bullets.
What's he saying?
Masterson's got live ammo. (CONTINUED)
© WILSON In the truck, he was showin off a boxful of 5-56's. Norman looks at Masterson.
What's this a military secret or something? Norman gets up and stands before Masterson. The rest watc
No fucking way.
Let me see your weapon.
Just stay on back.
Let me have the rounds, Masterson. Takes another step.
We'll divide them up, equally. Share them.
Bull shit. The others have moved in, close, but not too close.
It ain't right, Lonnie.
Masterson, I'm giving you a direct order. Give them to me. Masterson points his M-16 at Norman. (CONTINUED)
You come one step closer Norman, and I will. Tense pause.
Hell Lonnie! We're soldiering together!
It's a court martial offense. Give me the ammo and we'll drop the whole thing, or else I'm turning your ass in.
I don't give a shit what you do. From Masterson's side Calvelli moves in close, a flash -- a switchblade appears at Mastersons' throat.
Quit fucking around. Give him the bullets. Masterson slowly undoes his pocket. Tosses the box of shells to Norman. Calvelli puts the rifle away. Starts to move off.
Where does it go from here?
Court martial?
Yeah.
We're all soldiering together. Atwater comes up to Calvelli. (CONTINUED)
That's how they do these things in the Ivy League.
Villanova's not Ivy League...and I had this a long time before I went there.
You just brought it along for luck.
First time I ever spent a weekend with eight gun toting red-necks.
That's right. If we don't carry guns we're carrying ropes...R.C. colas and moon pies. Not too smart but we sure have fun. & Smiles and walks away.
The men trying to protect themselves from the bugs. Young speaks out to no one in particular.
We should be in maximum con- cealment. What the enemy sees, is what he takes.
Knock that enemy shit off. Norman strides up from the other side of the clearing. (CONTINUED)
Norman looks over at Wilson. 57.
I'm gonna post guard; two men, four hour shifts.
Start with me. Don't feel like sleeping anyway.
Longbrake, you take the other side. Youngblood and Masterson goon relief at 2300...
Norman moves off. Pause.
Keep the perimeter secured tight. WILSON . Yeah, yeah.
The password's "Werewolf". Got it?
Fassword? What are you talking about?
...What do we do now?
Nothing to do.
You play bridge by any chance?
Bridge? (CONTINUED)
© ATWATER Yeah. It's a card game.
I play.
Really...Hey, Norman, we got the one thing this outfit needed. A fourth for bridge...Hey Coach! Atwater takes out a soggy deck from his pack. Shuffles.
Both men at the perimeter of the clearing; Smith lights a joint...
How can you smoke that crap? a SMITH (takes a big hit) I ain't on your team, Coach.
God damn right you're not. You couldn't. make the Squad. That stuff kills the will to win.
How'd your boys do this year? He knows the answer.
Three and seven. Injuries to key personnel. Pause.
What do you do for a living, anyway?
(CONTINUED)
I work in the welfare department. Atwater shouts across the clearing to Youngblood.
Come on, Youngblood. We got us a couple of pigeons. Youngblood still looking at Smith, question marks surroun his face.
Welfare department?
Yeah. One day a week. Hard work going down there and picking up my check. Those lines get awful long.
Very funny. Ho, ho, ho. Now Smith is really having a good time with Youngblood.
Course I pick up a little cash pimping here and there but most of what I turn over comes from selling dope to high school kids. A long look from Youngblood.
You're a laugh riot, Smith. It's a good thing I don't believe you. He walks away and joins the waiting bridge game with Atwa Calvelli and Norman.
First light of day. The Squad has packed up for the day's march; first they have formed a loose circle.
Masterson, you hold point... Keep contact in file, don't start straggling. Anybody gets behind, start shouting, we'll all hold up. Atwater gives him the wagonmaster bit.
Yeah. Forward ya.
Knock that off. Okay. Let's go. As long as we stay North we'll be okay. The Squad heads into the dense forest.
Along the edge of the bayou. Masterson moving cautiously along, then stops...
Eight dead rabbits hanging from a tree limb alongside the trail. Thin cord around each of their throats. Each anima has been gutted.
Norman at the head of the column as the Squad comes up be Masterson. (CONTINUED )
Jesus.
What the hell's that supposed to mean?
To no one Pause. Don't mean nothing. Some dude just drying his skins.
Funny way of stretching a skin.
You sure these weren't left for us? in particular.
Masterson?
I ain't sure. But I know how I'd bet.
There's eight of them.
So what?
There's eight of us.
Let's keep going.
Right. We ain't gonna do any good right here no matter why they was left. (CONTINUED)
He moves off; the Squad slowly following.

head_text.subj: AT A FORK IN THE BAYOU MORNING

text: The men are bitten up, eyes bleary red. Beards stubbley. Here the bayou is narrower as it splits. The air hot and muggy. The men try to determine which way they should go.
What do you think?
Fork to the right's East. Probably easier to get where we want moving that way. They move off down the right fork; Atwater yells up at Norman from ten paces back.
You want to be headin North. The Interstate's North.
We're going to the Interstate.
Not if you go East. The Interstate's North.
Fuck you Atwater. What the fuck you know?
I know there's a big fireball in the sky that usually rises in the East and we're walking right into it. (CONTINUED)
You have to go East to go North, asshole.
Yeah, right.
You want to run that by me one more time? You got to go where to do which?
Jesus Christ.
It's my responsibility, Atwater. We're going East to get North.
Do what you want, zip. Atwater moves back to where Wilson and Youngblood are car the poncho stretcher. They all slosh off, following Norma
Staff command. They should be wondering about us, don't you think?
No, Not yet.
We've been out of contact for 12 hours.
Should be lookin' for us by now.
No way. We were supposed to meet the trucks twenty minutes ago. In another hour and a half the trucks (More) (CONTINUED)

ATWATER (cont'd) will show up. By two o'clock they'll ask around if anyone's seen us. At three, they'11 start checking the bars. By four they'll really get pissed. By five it will occur to some- body that maybe we got lost. By six the Captain will consider calling Battalion. At seven thirty he will. Battalion will tell him it's too late, there's nothing they can do till morning... That make you guys feel any better? They move past. cut TO:
blazing through the foliage overhead.
Norman plods by followed by Longbrake and Masterson carry the stretcher. Despite the fact it is only late morning, the day is already searingly hot.
He's getting heavy.
Shouldn't be too much longer.
Why don't we leave him and come back?
No. I told you before. (CONTINUED )
It's two hundred degrees...This son of a bitch is starting to blow up like a balloon. Taylor's body becoming distended beneath the poncho.
Don't be calling Taylor that.
He can't hear me.
I can! And, I don't want you calling him that.
Shit, Norman. The cocksucker's~ dead. I'm just talking about the body.
God damn it, Masterson! I don't want you calling him any of that shit!
Wilson, Smith, Youngblood.
Man, somebody put out the sun. My head's on fire.
Take your damn helmet off.
Want me to get skin cancer too? (CONTINUED)
Quit bellyaching like a bunch of women. My high school kids scrimage with full pads in weather hotter than this.
Hey, Coach.
Yeah?
Fuck. you.

Masterson running full speed through heavy undergrowth; dodging among trees and bushes, moving to the water's edg at a backwash feed along the bayou's perimeter. His foot falls squishing loudly against the humming sound of insects and strident bird calls. | Finally the rest of the Squad moves into view; Norman i first position, Atwater and Calvelli next, then Longbrake and Wilson. Youngblood and Smith trail along, Taylor's body stretchered between them. Norman looks up as Masterson runs to a full stop, then fi | to get his breath.
What the hell is it? More deep breaths.
Wha'd you find?
We got one up ahead.
(CONTINUED)
What's he talking about?
Something up ahead.
We got one of them. curt TO:

Military glasses with coordinate point lines. A Trapper i visible outside his shack on the bayou. He squats in the mud, mending his nets. His shack is four walls sitting up on sticks. A pirogue is pulled up on the bank.
That's him. That's the sonuva- bitch.
Let me look.
Where's the other one?
Far as I can tell, he's alone.
Masterson sights the Trapper in with his M-16; Norman pus his barrel aside.
No. We're gonna capture him.
What for? I can get him from here. (CONTINUED)
This is the U.S. Army, not the vigilantes. Atwater looks through the glasses.
You sure that's him? Hands the binoculars to Wilson.
Oh, man. No question about it. Norman pulls out the box of 5-56's and starts dispensing the shells.
Why don't you try talking to him before you start blowing his head off.
Masterson. Wilson. Longbrake. Remember the initial action must be decisive. Surprise is the key. Five bullets each.
Hey, you hear what I said?

I heard you...We'll talk to him after we've captured him. Rest of you are the rear element. Stay 100 meters behind us and keep down. Marry up when the objective is sealed off. Let's move out. They fan out and start through the swamp. Atwater and Calvelli watch them go. (CONTINUED)
| ©) CALVELLI You always get out of everything?
I don't see you stickin your hand up to volunteer.
Four of them, with automatic rifles, against the one guy with a knife...I make it even ] money.
They start trailing the men.

Carrying the stretcher, moving after Calvelli and Atwater cur TO: eS NORMAN - IN THE SWAMP He looks to his right, hand signals to Longbrake and Masterson to spread out and get down. Norman drops to his stomach and crawls, cradling the rifle. The side of the shack is visible...He fixes his bayonet.

head_text.subj: MASTERSON CRAWLING UP BEHIND THE SHACK

text: The Trapper has his back turned and sits framed by the supports. The stilts supporting the shack are high enough for a man to walk under.
crawling up on the other side. (CONTINUED)
To his far right; his M-16 ready.

Impossible to tell if this was one of the Cajun men encou tered earlier...Mending his net. Half his left arm missin He works the knife, sewing as he goes...Birds in flight m him look, and turn. He jumps up just as:
comes bursting out at him from all sides.
Freeze! The Trapper stands, holding his knife, the Riflemen come toward him.
Quoi? Qui @t es vous?
Easy now. We want to interrogate him. From all sides they close in on the Trapper; he falls int the Cajun patois.
Quiest que vous voulez, hein?
(pointing with rifle) Drop the knife.
Surrender.
Je nlai rien fait. Masterson moves even closer; eyes threatening, he gesture with his M-16.
You son of a bitch, drop the God damn knife. The Trapper realizes what he is being asked to do, he dro the hunting knife.
Qu'est que vous... WHACK! Wilson steps in and slams his rifle butt against t Trapper's mouth, instantly dropping him into the mud,
Holy shit!
You broke his jaw.
Yeah.
We want him to talk.
Knocked his mouth clear down to his ass.
How can he talk with a busted jaw?
That's his problem. Longbrake eyes the doorway to the shack. (CONTINUED)
Comeon, Lonnie. Let's see what's inside. Longbrake and Masterson move off toward the entrance to t Trapper's hovel.
Jesus, Wilson. What the hell did you do that for?
The son of a bitch.
They climb the rope ladder, position themselves on the po right and left of the door, rifles ready. With a nod, Masterson kicks the door and they move inside, ready for anything.
Norman's searching the Cajun, Wilson stands over the fall man...
Where's the rest of your bunch? How many more are there?
Ma bouche. Norman sees Atwater, Calvelli, Youngblood and Smith arriv through the trees.
Come on in, the area's secured. They come over. All gaze down at the Trapper. (CONTINUED)
We got us a prisoner.
Did you have to cut his arm off too? Masterson comes out on the shack porch, waving some pelts together. Longbrake's voice can be heard from inside the
All kinds a shit in here. He steps outside, next to Masterson.
Allright, no looting.
What do you say to that, Longbrake?
Fuck you, Norman.
Guard the prisoner, Wilson. Tie him up. And don't bust him again. Norman takes off for the shack. Atwater, Smith and Calvelli give Wilson a puzzled look.
You?
God damn right.
Why'd you want to go and do that for?
I don't know, I just got pissed. (CONTINUED)
Damn, man. This army bullshit is getting to you.

Norman walks in and finds Masterson and Longbrake tearing the place apart. It's a wooden plank hut, sealed with mud and thatched roof. Wooden shelves, with canned goods, bun burner, and kerosene lamp. Some animal traps. Rag quilt o the floor over a swamp moss mattress. Playboy centerfold wall next to picture of Christ and crucifix.
Get drunk, Norman. Longbrake hands Norman a jug...He takes a swig.
Yecch!
Look at this knife I found. Holds a huge hunting knife, suddenly a spotlight shines o both of them.
God damn, this boy's a poacher. Masterson holds two dry cells taped together with a big b
We poached the poachers.
He shined his last gator.
He don't Look big enough to night wrestle gators. (CONTINUED)
He ain't. That's what the light's for. Freezes ‘em. Longbrake is pocketing the canned goods.
Turnips, corn, white beans, rice, hog head cheese...
Here's a box of shells, half-full... They start to leave.
Knives, guns, supplies...I'd say we conducted a pretty successful raid. n
As. Norman, Longbrake and Masterson approach with all the goodies. .
Wilson, I told you to tie the prisoner up. :
Now how am I supposed to tie the man up when he only has but one hand to tie?
Tell. you how to do it. You tie it around his. fuckin neck and lynch the sonofabitch.
It's a great old Southern tradition but maybe we ought to try talking to him first. (CONTINUED)
Pause.
Who speaks French...Youngblood?
Yeah. Wanders off toward the hut; pays no attention to them.
I'll give it a try. Moves to the Trapper.
You: speak English? The Trapper shakes his head.
Hier. Quelq'un...shit. I can't remember how to say ‘shoot’...
How about bang bang?
Hier quelq'un.,.bang (indicates shooting) +.eun ami...
J'ai fait rien.
I think he's saying he didn't do anything. It doesn't sound like any French I ever heard. te MASTERSON What the fuck is this? I saw him. (CONTINUED)
Christ, yes.
Iwas there too. I couldn't swear to anything...I can't even remember if the guy had one arm.
While all this has been going on, he has walked over to t shack and begins climbing the rope ladder.

Youngblood looks around... Moves off, kicks an old paint The red paint inside is still good. He looks at the ax an steel animal traps, finds a glass jar and picks up the ke sene lamp...starts pouring the kerosene into the jar.
Norman is reasserting his authority.
We'll take this man back with us for interrogation at Staff Command, then he'll stand trial. Atwater and Calvelli look at each other. Longbrake offers the jug of moonshine.
Anyone want some Cajun whiskey?
About time one of you said somethin' makes sense. (CONTINUED)
Get us high as a Georgia pine. Smith drinks then passes it over.
If you don't go blind.
Okay, listen up. Everybody over to the rain barrel, fill your canteens. I want to put some miles between.us and here. We should make the Interstate by this afternoon.
Youngblood is enjoying a private joke, chuckling to himse The paint can now open and brush in hand. He removes his shirt and calmly paints a red cross on his chest.

head_text.subj: THE SQUAD AT THE WATER BARREL

text: Longbrake and Masterson are in a water fight, the rest ar finishing up as Youngblood comes down the ladder, Calvell is the first to see him and the Molotov cocktail Youngblo holds in his hand.
Oh fuck.
(laughing) And the mark of Cain shall stain them forever. Youngblood is down the ladder, and the entire Squad can n see him as he lights the rag fuse. (CONTINUED)
Hit it! They run for cover...dive for the ground.
Slowly walks away from the shack, the fuse burning...Then turns'-and throws the jar at the shack. i
Fire one!
as. the shack gets blown away. Brilliant orange flames ro upward as everything erupts in fire, sending splinters of burning wood flying into the bayou...Debris and flames fi the air.
walks calmly to where the rest of the Squad has dived for cover. He stops, looks at them...
That'll teach them to fuck with us.
Yeah. Right. Can't argue with that.
What the hell did you paint the cross on your chest for, Youngblood?
Just part of the joke. He Laughs.  ©@
silently looking at the ruin of his cabin.
hitches up his rifle.
Let's get going, Norman. He starts off. cur TO:
Norman leading the Squad slowly forward; Masterson not on point but simply holding ‘position alongside the teamlead
He sure demolitioned that shack. Blew it clear to kingdom come..
Yeah. Only problem is that it might. have been a signal for this cocksucker's relatives to gather round.
You really think we still got to worry about those bastards?
Shit, yes. But I'll tell you who ought to worry about them a lot more than me and you.
You don't have to tell me. (CONTINUED )
i
Longbrake 81.
They think you guys are bad luck.
They might be right. I been hanging out with niggers my whole life. I haven't got a break yet. is running out of patience. » LONGBRAKE Any chance we're ever going to get out of here?
God damn right. I figure two hours tops before we hit the- Interstate.
Yeah. Either two hours from the Interstate or New York by Friday.
The Squad comes moving forward.
God damn it, Norman, where's the highway? It's been three fucking hours.
It's right around here, close by.
Yeah, right, Norman.. It used to run right through here. |. Those ecology boys must have moved it. (CONTINUED)
. Fuck you, Atwater. Atwater calls ahead to Longbrake, twenty yards to the fro
Hey Longbrake, you got anything to say to Norman?
Fuck you, Norman.
Thanks, Longbrake.
The iron jaws of six steel traps are just visible above t crude cover of twigs and moss. The Guardsmen move right for them, unaware. Norman is heading straight into one, unseeing.
Hey! He grabs Norman.
What?
Look what ya almost stepped in!
Jesus Christ! They gaze at the open jaws. ‘ NORMAN Some. kind of fuckin bear trap.
Lookit this bastard. : Ss "(CONT INUED)
Atwater, Calvelli, Wilson and Smith move up.
Eight of them, all laid out.
Just like the rabbits.
They was set for us?
Shit, yes.
Either us or the last eight bears in the state of Louisiana. Masterson releases one by ‘shoving a stick into the The trap snaps shut, it's jaws clang out, biting.
Just like a steel pussy.
Really? What kind of girls you been hanging out with?
Good thing you spotted them, Longbrake.
Don't mention it. Anytime you need help, Norman. opening. Calvelli. looks at the Cajun, points to the steel traps.
Q'est que c'est? No response. (CONTINUED)
What did you ask him?
What they were doing here... Masterson grabs the Trapper and starts squeezing his brok jaw.
Okay you sonuvabitch. Still no response.
Are there any more? Huh? I'm . talking to you.
He ain't gonna tell you shit. You know that Lonnie. Masterson releases the Trapper.

Okay. They didn't get us and they're not gonna, we wasted enough time. Let's saddle up; the Interstate ain't far. Longbrake again moves to point. Smith flanks the right si of the group; moving along the trail's edge...
Don't make any unnecessary noise. No talking in formation. He. takes six steps when, from out of nowhere, a wooden s rips deep into Smith's mid-section.
his face frozen in death, eyes staring at the object stuc (CONTINUED)
in his chest. The stake is fastened to a branch and keeps him standing upright, until his dead weight finally break free.
Unable to move, they only stare in horror and silence.,. finally:

Jesus Christ. Calvelli moves over the dead body to examine the weapon. The stake is finely hand honed and tied to a branch, alon with another pointed spear, several feet away. Calvelli slaps the second bent branch with his rifle, releasing another stake which snaps into place a few feet from his stake. aad CALVELLI These fuckers are after us. They really are. The rest of the Squad staring at Smith's body.

Within a small clearing. The Squad stands in prayer befor two graves. Crude wet-wooden branch crosses. Masterson stands guard with the Prisoner and acts as sentry...Young blood is speaking in a low, deep tone.

Qur Father who art in Heaven, hallowed be Thy name. Thy Kingdom come, Thy will be done, on Earth as it is in Heaven. Give us this day our daily bread, and forgive us our trespasses, as we. forgive those who trespass against us. Lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from evil. For Thine is the Kingdom... (CONTINUED)
Long pause.

For Thine is the Kingdom... For Thine is the Kingdom... Long pause, Youngblood continues staring straight ahead. Nervous looks from the rest of the Squad as they turn the attention from the two shallow graves to the hulking Youn blood -- He continues to stare abstractly at his feet.
For Thine is the Kingdom, and the Power, and the Glory forever. Amen. . Youngblood raises his look to the graves.
We give this prayer as dead men asking for our own salvation. Norman steps into the center of the clearing, standing be the entire Squad.

Bullshit. I don't want to hear that kind of talk...We're at war. That's all there is to it, sol want you looking like soldiers not mail men. Weapons carried at ready...we've got three hours of daylight left and we're headin' North...Let's move. He turns and moves across the clearing; the Squad look at one another momentarily and then begin to follow.
The Squad appears, slowly trudging forward. Norman holds them up in the center of the open space. (CONTINUED)
This is it. We'll bivouac here. Clearing this big will make it tought for those bastards to sneak up on us. Youngblood sits down on a log then looks continuously at the ground before his feet.

Yeah. Right. Now let's get a few things straight, Norman. Tomorrow morning helicopters will be out looking for us. Damn good chance they'll find us if we stay in clear ground. So what we have to worry about until then is the Cajuns...

We don't know the enemy's dispo- sition or his strength. He may have the advantage of familiar terrain, but we have the advan- tage of military training. Remember the 5 D's. Detect, deny, deceive, defend, and destroy.
Great speech, Norman. But I want to make our odds a little better.
What are you going for? Atwater points at the Trapper, still being covered by Masterson.
Maybe they want him back. Maybe that's all they want. Let's take the chance and let him go. (CONTINUED)
Bullshit. He killed Taylor. The only place he's going is with us.
They're fixin' to kill us all.
You got it.
Gag and blindfold the Prisoner, Wilson.
Norman, you're a dumb asshole, Norman steps forward and slams Atwater in the face with h right fist.
still sitting on the log, staring downward.
' speaks very calmly to the now flush-faced Atwater.
I don't want any more talk like that.
Yeah, right. You got the stripe, Chief.
God damn right I do. He looks over at Longbrake. (CONTINUED)
The jokes are over. Then at the Squad.

Tomorrow morning we're heading North with the Prisoner. The man that killed Crawford Taylor, the man whose buddies. killed Tyrone Smith...In case you forgot Atwater, they were. friends of ours. Long pause.
Now let's get unpacked and bedded down, I'll post security. No fire tonight. The Squad drop their packs, begin undoing them.
looking at Atwater as he rubs the spot alongside his chin where Norman hit him. He moves closer; Atwater unsnaps the buttons on his back- pack...
You might be right about the Cajun. Atwater looks up at him.
Why the hell didn't you say something?
I don't know...I just can't believe any of this. (CONTINUED)
Let me know when you start.
still sitting on the log.
Moonlight is now the only source of illumination.

tied to a tree near the edge of the clearing. A sock stuf into his mouth and held in place with friction tape. His eyes turn and follow Longbrake moving across in front him, approaching Norman who is busy working while seated a canvas groundcloth.
stops to watch Norman put small rocks into an empty can o peas taken from the shack.
I got something to tell you, Norman...hey what's that for?
Fragmentation...Remember your training. You shouldn't of been sleeping in the survival class.
Yeah. I musta missed that one. (CONTINUED)
® NORMAN a: S, size up the situation. understand what you're up against. R, remember where you are. V, value living. 1, what's I?
I don't remember.
Improvise. Even blank rounds can save your life. He pours the gunpowder of a shell into the can.
Atwater told me to come over and talk to you.
What's he want? ‘ ’ LONGBRAKE s It's Youngblood. There's something wrong with him. He won't talk. Atwater says he's gone crazy. You better come on over...I think Atwater's right.
now standing near the comatose Youngblood; the rest of th Squad behind, looking over his shoulder.
Youngblood, look, we all have had a rough time and I can understand if you're not feeling too good...Why don't you just talk to us about it. (CONTINUED)
No response.
Come on, Youngblood. No response.
I'm giving you an order, Youngblood. Now God damn it talk to us. No response. Norman turns to the rest of the Squad. Shrugs.
I don't know.
I do. The motherfucker's crazy.
What are we going to do with him?
Leave him there. Maybe he'll feel better in the morning.

Bullshit! You're going to tie his-ass up, Norman. This is the guy that made his own bomb, remember? I don't want him walking around here tonight, while we're sleeping. The entire Squad now staring at Norman.
He's right.
He is, Norman. (CONTINUED)
Norman looks over at Masterson.
Won't hurt any to tie him up.
If he's tied up we lose potential firepower. 4 ATWATER. Jesus Christ, get a God damn rope and quit jerking off about firepower. .
Remember what happened the last time you shot your mouth off to me, Atwater.
Come on, Norman. He's right. He's Pause. Turns and
way too big and dangerous.
Okay, Wilson, there's forty feet of rope in my pack. Go get it. walks away.
Heavy rain is falling.
on sentry pulls his Pause. anes, 93. duty at the far side of the clearing. He stands, listening...Thinks he heard something...sits back down an Poncho over his head, (CONTINUED )

Then again he stands; listens and looks... He can see the rest of the Squad sleeping; The dark fores surrounding all...A twig cracks in the bush...after a mom Calvelli starts to move quietly; not waking any of the ot Calvelli now travels through the underbrush to the edge o the bayou where he sees:

holding the Trapper's head under water. The Cajun is on his stomach, a rope ties: his arms behind his back -- Mas son lets his head up momentarily then pushes it back into the muddy water. The Trapper goes under, spitting bubbles
What the hell you doing?
This man's going to talk to me.
Let him up.
You stay out of it. Keeps holding his head under. Pause.
God damn it let him up!
Sure. Masterson yanks the Trapper's héad out of the water, pull him up by the hair. The Trapper surfaces, lungs bursting for air.
Now you happy? (CONTINUED)
Masterson shoves the Trapper back in. In a flash, Calvelli's right hand slashes out - the switc blade cutting along Masterson's poncho...a warning slash.

That's the second time you pulled that on me. Masterson takes out his bayonet. The long blade glistens the night rain. . Calvelli backs away. Masterson keeps coming. Slash...slash. Calvelli has no choice. The two men circle.

Okay, you got it. Masterson lunges for the gut. Calvelli takes the feint an leans back as Masterson continues the thrust upwards, bar raking Calvelli from jaw to cheek. A fine line of blood seeps out of the razored cut. Masterson smiles. They circle each other, feinting for an opening; Masterso bayonet cutting circles through the falling rain. Calvelli's left hand grabs Masterson's right wrist in mid air, pulling it sideways, pitching Masterson off balance. Calvelli pounces, the two men go down, each holding the other's knife wrist.
Once, twice. On the third roll the flash of the Cajun Trapper coming to his feet breaks Calvelli's concentratio For a moment, their eyeballs lock. (CONTINUED)

Kill him. They roll over again. Calvelli on top, on bottom, on top again. Loses the switchblade. His leverage has Masterson's wrist bent backwards, forcin the bayonet from Masterson's grip. They roll over and com apart. Each man up quickly, each dives for the blade lost in the mud. Calvelli now has the bayonet. Masterson now has the switc blade. Masterson lunges. Catches Calvelli off guard. Calvelli throws his left arm up to block the stab. The switchblade plunges into the lower flesh of Calvelli's bicep and stic Calvelli's knife hand lashes up, misses, but his knuckles catch Masterson flush on the jaw, a solid right hook. Masterson stumbles backwards, leaving the switchblade stu in Calvelli's arm.
Norman, Atwater, Wilson come running up through the under brush. Stop and stare at the two struggling men.

leaps on top of Masterson; they both go down hard... Masterson on his back; Calvelli on top of him. Calvelli's left wrist is pressed tight under Masterson's pinning him, gagging him. Calvelli's shaking right hand holds the bayonet shoulder high...Masterson is totally vu nerable, his empty arms stretched out in surrender...tota at Calvelli's mercy. Calvelli brings the bayonet up higher. (CONTINUED)

Kill him. Hesitates. Higher. Hesitates. Then plunges it deep into Masterson's heart. The sound of laughter. Calvelli keeps leaning on the bayonet...All his weight... Then slowly comes back up, staring at the dead man beneat him. He can't believe what he's done. Can't believe it. But it's there. Staring up at him. He did this. With his own hand. Calvelli gets to his feet. Sees the shocked faces of Atwater, Norman and Wilson; dis covering for the first time that they've been watching. Pause. Wilson walks over to Masterson's body; looks at his unblinking eyes.
He's dead. Masterson's dead. Pause.,
Your Prisoner got away, Norman. Pause.
What were you doing fighting each other? (CONTINUED)
Norman stands there, unable to comprehend.
Jesus. We're not supposed to fight each other. Longbrake arrives, crashing through the vegetation -- he sees Masterson's body stretched before him.
Lonnie! He rushes over. Looks at Calvelli still holding the bayonet.

You mother fucker! Springs at him but is caught and held back by Wilson and Norman. Longbrake wrestles against their grasp -- fightin to get at Calvelli who stands calmly looking at him, hand at his sides. e LONGBRAKE Let me get him, God damn it, let me get him.
keeps looking straight at Calvelli.
bound by heavy ropes, standing erect, almost at attention His eyes remain clouded over, unseeing.
Twenty yards beyond Youngblood a few hours after Masterso
(CONTINUED)
death. The rain continues to pour down. Atwater and Wilson are digging a grave with their short infantry shovels.
Longbrake squatting down by Masterson's poncho covered bo Watching as the grave expands with each bite of the spade His steel helmet shining in the downpour.
Calvelli seated; calmly, emotionlessly watching the grave digging. Norman crosses behind him and approaches Atwater and Wilson.
How many graves we gonna be leavin back here? Norman arrives in time to hear this last remark.
No more of ours, I can tell you that.
Yeah. You can tell me that. Calvelli stands, calls over to the gravesite.
Be quiet.
You talkin to me?
I'm talking to everybody. (CONTINUED)
Norman turns away from Calvelli, unable to face him; Wils and Atwater continue shoveling.

The Squad huddled together in the pouring rain; forty yar beyond them is Masterson's freshly dug grave marked with wooden branch cross, steel helmet on the cross strut. The Guardsmen are all shivering inside their ponchos; their packs in place ready to march...Atwater holding the end of the rope that binds Youngblood.

We have three casualties, we're not gonna have any more. Survival is a mental outlook. Shock and fear can be overcome by a sense of responsibility; Loyalty to country and military duty...Desire to return to home and family. If you are not prepared mentally to overcome all obstacles and hardships, the chances of coming out alive are greatly reduced.
Getting wet listening to all this, Norman.
God damn you Atwater. I'm trying to do my best. It ain't easy.
I know you are, Norman.
You figure you can do any better? (CONTINUED)
Pause. Longbrake 101.
Yeah.
I'm the team leader! You ain't even an E-5. You're...you're only an E-4!
Big deal.
I'm with you. Sorry, Norman. NORMAN . The rest of you guys feel that way?
Longbrake?
Norman, you promise that this asshole's gonna be court mar- tialed.
He's got to be. He killed a fellow soldier. looks across at Atwater, shrugs.
Changing horses in midstream never did make much sense.
Calvelli?
What's this voting bullshit? You know the way? (CONTINUED)
@® ATWATER Yeah. I can find it, if it ever stops raining.
Then let's go.
Come on Youngblood, let's go home. Atwater tugs on Youngblood's rope, starts leading him awa
Wait a minute Atwater. You can't just march off. We're a Squad. A unit...
Fuck him. Let him go.
It's desertion. s CALVELLI Right.
Atwater and Calvelli and Wilson start off. The other two watch. Atwater stops.
You coming? Norman moves toward Atwater. Then Longbrake.
Atwater's tone to Norman is soft, gentle.
You're still in charge, Norman. I'm just the guide. They trudge away at an angle to the rising sun.
More heavy rain. The men are soaked, shaking, filthy, hun tense. The surrounding vegetation is impenetrable, allowi little sunlight to filter through; moss hanging from ‘the like bearded columns.
Leading the way. Behind Youngblood, quietly accepting his leashed condition, are Norman, then Longbrake -- Wilson trails.
Arm okay?
Yeah, it's okay. Pause.
Want to talk about Masterson? Look, I know he was a real son of a bitch.
I don't want to talk about him.
It was self-defense. Pause.
Pisses me off, those other guys gettin our whores while we're out here.
Do me a favor. Shut up. They move forward in silence.
Still trailing the rest of the Squad. Bird calls, branche and twigs snapping underfoot, then another sound. Twang. ‘ Twang. Twang. Twang. Wilson stops, pulls his M-16 to the ready position.

Hey. The others ahead stop...listen. Twang, twang, twang. A Jew's harp, not far off. Wilson suddenly wheels and fires into the swamp. The rest of the Squad drop. and move to cover, sighting along thei M-16's. All is still... Quiet... Twang. Twang. Twang.
Wilson?
I thought I saw something.
Where?
Over there.
You sure?
You heard it.
Nothing now. (CONTINUED)
Carefully, they get up and continue walking along the edg of the bayou. Twang. Twang. Twang.

Motherfuckers! He snaps. Starts to run off through the brush, firing his M-16. Twang. Blast. Twang. Blast. Wilson continues running, chasing the sound...Stops, his face twisting into an agonized mask...He tries to scream, mouth open, nothing coming out. When the cry finally bursts out it is a deafening cry of shock and terror. Along the edge of the bayou in front of him a scarecrow looms...
Smith's black skin stretched out on the two crossed poles Taylor's white head sits at the top of the pole where Smi neck ends.
As the rest of the Squad come pounding up behind him...
Holy. Christ.
They dug ‘em up.
Jesus. Jesus. Jesus.
His eyes take in the Scarecrow. (CONTINUED)
I pray the Lord my soul I pray the Lord my soul I pray the Lord my soul Twang, twang, twang.
Hot, muggy. The Squad moving in file; Atwater holding to the edge of the bayou. Atwater.
Atwater, you still want write me up a policy?
Don't have my forms with me.
That ain't funny.
to take. to take. to take...
leading the way -- still Wilson pulls alongside to
Nobody ever wants insurance till they need it...Look Cleotis, right now there's state troopers, heli- copters, hound dogs, everybody in Louisiana's out looking for us...
They better make it quick.
I want you to remember this tomorrow when I make you sign. A few more paces; Norman calls out from twenty yards back (CONTINUED )
Atwater. Hold up. We'll take two minutes rest. The Squad pulls up...Seat themselves, remove their helmet Youngblood remains standing, almost like a huge fleshy ro at rest.
Lights a cigarette...his last. He crushes up the package, tosses it away...Looks across at Atwater who is cleaning glasses on his shirtfront. Calvelli rises, moves to Atwat looms over him.
Get up.
What?
Get up. I want to talk to you.
Yeah?
Away from the rest of them. Atwater stands, he and Calvelli move away from the others Atwater turns back to Calvelli, curious about the moment.
Okay. Pause.
I want to know what the fuck's going on.
I don't get you. (CONTINUED)
Pause. Pause. o 108.

I'll make it real simple...I'm down here two weeks and get sent out with a bunch of rednecks and two spades, all of a sudden guys start coming out of the trees and killing us...Now I'll ask you again. What the fuck's going on? What do they want?
I want to know what the rules are.
I figure you know better than me. You're the one that brought the knife. And you're the one that used it...

I'll tell you something. I'ma city boy, born and raised in Baton Rouge, and went to Vanderbilt, sell insurance for my father's company and don't work too hard...You want to know what's going on back here? I haven't got the slightest fucking idea. God damn Cajuns are weird and they're killing us... Calvelli shrugs.
Right back where I grew up.
That's what I thought. I'm depending on you.
When you go into somebody's territory...
Yeah.
They want to kill you. Turns and walks back toward the others.

The Squad moves along in silence, all of them save Youngb are apprehensive. As they pass, backs turned... Something moves along the bank of the bayou...The mud ris in a heap, dripping...from the slime a form emerges...
All mire and hair, a troglodyte in appearance...He aims h rifle at the Squad's back, smiles and fires.
As the swamp explodes with gun fire.

Ambush! Snipers! They dive for cover. Gunfire comes at them from all over. Front, rear, side. The Squad shoots back blindly, sprayin everything...Youngblood alone stands. Atwater rolls back for the abandoned rope end...grabs, tugs it and brings Youngblood down.
Youngblood! For Christ's sake!
From behind the stump of a dead cottonwood.
They got us flanked. We're pinned down.
Motherfucker! Norman fires twice then is out of ammo...
Cover me!
With what? All I got is blanks. Norman's contact with reality is now problematical.
No radio contact or ammo or air support, mortars. We got nothing. How we supposed to fight on that?
Don't ask me. You're the one supposed to know. .
Fire the God damn blanks... Wilson opens up, Norman breaks for it.

He crawls thirty yards, dodges, runs...his M-16 left behi with Wilson. A burst of rifle fire and he darts in that direction...dives for cover behind a huge cypress and sit panting for a moment. Mudman appears thirty yards before him, firing...but has no idea of Norman's new position -- (CONTINUED)

Norman reaches into his pocket and pills out the can he l with gunpowder and pebbles. The can is bound tight with v and a rag fuse is stuffed in the top. Shaking, Norman fum for a match, and lights the rag. It ignites. He holds the grenade, peeks out from behind the tree, stands and throw the grenade at the Mudman...A perfect toss.
As the grenade hits and extinguishes itself. Nothing. No explosion. Mudman turns, sees Norman, and fires.
Running like hell, bullets kicking all around him...
Norman tears. past them...
Pull back! Retreat! They move away to the continuing shots of the Cajuns. Sweating, panting, the men trip and stumble over vines an roots, sloshing in mud. Branches slash at their faces...
I can't go no more.
Come on, Longbrake. They pound forward, regroup, hurry on.
They after us?
Keep going. (CONTINUED)
More running forward, trees, limbs, underbrush, mud...But no more rifle fire. Norman pulls them up. Atwater is pant fighting for oxygen.
No.
I don't hear anything.
Yeah, I hear it now. Norman frantically starts digging through his pockets.
Helicopter!

My mirror. Where's my mirror! Through the mist, skirting along the treetops, the heli- copter, coming right at them. The men start waving, jumping, shouting. Norman is flashing his mirror...The Chopper passes right over their heads...and is gone. The men of the lst Squad stand in disbelief. Longbrake st walking off, after the helicopter.
Qver here, over here. - Norman slowly starts to put away his mirror, then decid first clean its surface on his poncho.
I don't see how he missed us.
I could see his face.
Why didn't he see my signal? (CONTINUED)
Not enough sun.
Hey? Where's Longbrake?
I don't know.
He was here a minute ago.
Now running through the swamp after the vanished helicopt He tries to move faster...faster...faster...oblivious to brush and moss.

Shallow water and mud. Longbrake comes bursting through t So surrounding vegetation and begins splashing through th opening in the forest -- his face turned upward, still va looking for the chopper. Then he slows down. Slower. Slower. Full stop. | Begins to sink. Quicksand.
cur TO:
Norman yelling...
Longbrake! Longbrake! (CONTINUED)
Looks back at the others.
Spread out. We have to find him... Buddy teams, you and me, Wilson. First team to find him fire a blank every five minutes. Other team will work its way there.
What if we don't find him?
Wait an hour, fire five blanks and then one every five minutes. Both teams will work back to each others. Norman and Wilson start out; Atwater looks at Calvelli, shrugs.
Come on, Youngblood. Jerks the rope.
He sees something...reaches out..pleading to be saved...
ten or eleven years old, sits at the edge of the bog; Fascinated, he watches Longbrake sink...Laughs at him.
leading Youngblood through the swamp. (CONTINUED)
Longbrake! Longbrake! You dumb red-neck where are you! Longbrake! cur TO:

They move, cautiously looking...then leap backward, start as a Cajun with a huge black beard appears before them, Mudman behind them...off to one side a third Cajun with a Hawk-like face. Blackbeard steps forward, holding a razor edged Bowie knife... cur To:

up to his neck...the Cajun boy watches Longbrake slowly disappear. Mouth, nose, eyes, forehead. A few gurgling bubbles and the swamp is once again still...The Boy moves off into the dense foliage and vanishes. Atwater's voice can be heard faintly in the distance.
Longbrake!
Norman leaps toward Hawk-face, swings his rifle by the ba and pole-axes the big man. Killing him instantly. Another Cajun appears at his side, Norman bayonets his mid-sectio
Take off! Wilson starts running across the clearing. Norman reaches for Hawk-face's rifle...and is brought down by Mudman's (CONTINUED)
bullet, straight through the back and heart.

running through the swamp. Never looking back, he dodges darts, cutting and weaving through the towering ferns... Eyes and lungs on fire, he staggers through the thicket a mud...doubles over, holding his side, breathing like a lo motive. He splashes his face from a pool of swamp water, rinsing and spitting, then forces himself on...Running ag then trips, recovers, scrambling now on all fours, knees touching the earth...He pitches forward _and drops exhaus shaking, afraid to move.
Coming at Wilson, he slides back, away, as they move sile closer. Wilson is on his feet now, back to a tree, corner He screams and lunges at the Cajuns, swinging his M-16 li a ball bat. cur To:
Late afternoon sun; Atwater, Calvelli and Youngblood. Atwater fires five blanks. They wait. And wait. And wait.
The only thing we're doing is telling the Cajuns where we are.
They haven't had too much trouble finding us up to now.
It's just part of the joke. (CONTINUED)
Which makes no sense, but he is quite mad.
Pause, he shouts again.

Let's go. They move up a steep embankment, cross through a ridge of ferns and begin a descent toward a new series of bayous a interlocking waterways. The maze of brackish water and dense foliage stretches before them like a vast crossword puzzle...beyond lies a forest of dead trees, leafless branches pointing upward, almost in surrender.
Jesus.
No fucking way out. Pause.
Where the fuck are the helicopters? Where the fuck are we?
I thought you were the one that knew.
