I know where we're going. I just don't know where we are.
Yeah...We better find something to eat.
Along the edge of the murky water. The three men trudge forward. Youngblood trailing, still being led by Atwater holding the short throw of rope.
Wait. Calvelli stops; Atwater points to a large nest-like congl eration of mud and branches.
There's food.

What? Atwater goes to the dark mound, kicks it, waits, then war kicks it again. Suddenly an explosion of mud and water as a small alligator thunders out of its nest and into the r beyond...Atwater watches it go then reaches inside the ne and hands Calvelli a large, leathery egg. He reaches back inside and pulls out two more, gives one to Youngblood. Atwater stands holding one in his hand.
Protein. Atwater smiles. Starts to bite, then waits for Calvelli, who tops his and sucks it down. Atwater looks at him.
I don't think so.
Come on, before it hatches.
You liked yours so much, you can have mine. (CONTINUED)
Eat it. You're going to need all the strength you can get...I don't want you falling down on me. Atwater downs his.
Chow time, Coach. Going to untie you. Atwater begins to loosen Youngblood's ropes. cur To:

head_text.subj: WALKING DOWN A SMALL BAYOU LATE

text: The three men now close to the limits of endurance. They move slowly along the deep banks, water covered with gree pads. Youngblood remains untied.

Atwater and Calvelli dig at the steep walls with their bayonets, making natural depressions wider. They claw at the dirt, passing it out in the steel pots. Youngblood stands watching the men carve out shelter for the evening
The three of them lie on their sides. A small fire is boiling water in one of the steel helmets.
Tomorrow this time you'll be sitting in your den with a beer and the tee vee, listening to your old lady's bullshit. Pause. (CONTINUED)
Yeah. Calvelli starts cleaning his wound.
Full of dirt. ~
Infected?
Probably.
Let me help you with that. Atwater wraps up Calvelli's arm.
Some nurse.
Yeah, but I'm easy. Pause.
Terrific state you got here, Atwater. They send out two helicopters. :
What do you want them to do send out the National Guard?
Sun starts to filter through the covering fog. Atwater sleeping heavily, exhausted...Calvelli in a sentry positi fatigue has taken its toll with him as well -- he sleeps (CONTINUED)

fitfully...Youngblood nowhere to be seen. The ground begins to shake, a roaring noise...Calvelli aw as the sound and shaking increase...Then suddenly from fi yards away a train whistle blasts...from out of nowhere a locomotive and flatcars roar by at seventy miles an hour. The railroad embankment obscured from Calvelli's vision b the dense foliage. Atwater leaps to Calvelli's side. They both run toward th embankment, shouting to each other above the roar.
Where the fuck did this come from?
I don't know but I love it. Big smiles on both men's faces; they slap five. After a few moments, the end of the train whips by...
Maintaining their smiles...
Never been so glad... The eyes of both men tighten.

head_text.subj: THE OTHER SIDE OF THE TRACK

text: Youngblood's body hanging from the limb of a cypress tree the rope that Atwater bound him with now forms a hangman' noose.
Atwater and Calvelli slowly approach the corpse.
Poor son of a bitch. (CONTINUED)
Did he do it himself or did they help him? Calvelli shrugs.
Doesn't make any difference now.
Two figures against the horizon line trudging slowly forw Thick foliage to their left, a long low reach of bayou to the right.
Across the stretch of water a small movement...
Over there. Atwater looks.
What is it? Both men staring.

A truck. Fucking truck. He starts running...Atwater lopes after him, tossing his rifle aside...the truck almost looks as if it's floating the water...they move closer...the horizon line changing with their progress -- crushed-shell road revealed on the far side of the bayou. As the truck moves toward the railroad crossing Calvelli starts running faster, screaming... (CONTINUED)
Hey! Wait!
| Has made a full stop at the crossing. The vehicle is a bed, old, delapidated, rusty...An Elderly Cajun Couple in front seat. Calvelli runs up, Atwater a few paces behind.

Wait...uh hello... The Elderly Man smiles nervously back at the two dishevel soldiers. The Woman doesn't smile at all. A very long pause. Atwater and Calvelli so moved by their first contact with civilization that words are difficult...Atwater notices t reluctance of the couple. ress . ATWATER They're scared.
What?
Your guns. The way we look. Calvelli sets his M-16 down.
No bullets anyway. Smiles at the Elderly Cajun Man and Woman.
You want lift?
Yes. Oh God yes, do we ever. (CONTINUED)
Both Cajuns laugh.
You get in back.
Sure.. Next town. Right?
Sure. Sure. The Elderly Man's grasp on English is limited; a problem little matter to Atwater and Calvelli, they hop on the fl bed of the pick-up...The battered vehicle pulls off.
The flat-bed pick-up chugging along, Atwater and Calvelli stretched out in back. The truck turns down a narrow lane
Watching the marsh country slip by on either side of them
How far?
You're asking me? The flat-bed moves into a clearing...Many cars and trucks parked nearby; Campers, hay wagons...
What the hell?

head_text.subj: EXT, CLEARING NEXT TO A HUGE BAYOU

text: Two hundred or so Cajuns; men, women, children, and assor animals, have gathered next to a huge bayou for what is (CONTINUED)
known to the locals as a Shivaree. Music, dancing, gumbo, crayfish, jambalaya, alcohol make for a generally festive atmosphere.
The truck bearing Atwater and Calvelli rolls into the cle
Hearing the music look over the truck to see what's going The sight of two hundred Cajuns even at play is not reass
What the hell: is this?
I think it's one of those Cajun luau's you were talking about.

What happened to the town they were taking us to? Atwater shrugs. The truck has now stopped in what is curr passing for the parking area. Atwater and Calvelli jump d off the truck to confront the couple getting out of the t
Where's the town? We want to go to town.
Eat first. Go ‘town later.
No. We want to go to town now.
First, eat. Have good time. (CONTINUED)

Shivaree. You have good time. Town after. The couple is open, friendly and not to be dissuaded. Atw and Calvelli exchange a look and allow themselves to be l to the clearing. The woman continues chattering to them a they move off.
You eat. You drink. You have good time...

Atwater and Calvelli cleaning themselves up in the bayou. Children playing in the water around them. A short distan away, the band plays enthusiastically for a.crowd of danc clogging on wooded planking laid out on the soft ground.
What do you think?
I think I feel better. Cleaner anyway.
What about safer?
Yeah...0On the other hand I don't think I'd lie down and go to sleep.
Maybe we should forget about Mom and Dad and try for town by ourselves.
What for? If they're still hunting us, they'll find us in the swamps. We'll be safer here. (CONTINUED)
Okay, but we grab a ride with the first car that leaves. They are startled by a popping sound behind them. They wheel around...
A sweet faced, smiling girl of about twelve has opened a of cans of beer which she now offers to our boys. Their s reaction makes her a little nervous. They smile.
Thank you.
Merci. She smiles and runs off.
Relax, boy. These are the good Cajuns.
(unconvinced) Yeah. You relax. Atwater takes a long swallow of beer.

The party is now in full swing. Calvelli is at the food table being served a huge plate of crawfish and gumbo. General gaiety abounds everywhere except Calvelli's face. As he takes his plate and moves through the crowd.
Strange smiles, missing teeth...All appear sinister to Ca
He sits down under a tree. He starts to eat, but continua looks around.

He scans the dancers, the band, everybody. He seems to ca people staring at him and then looking away as their eyes A pirogue poles up the bayou and beaches. Two men get out this distance they could be the two Cajuns who killed Tay
He stares at them. Atwater suddenly appears and sits down next to him.
What's the matter with you, boy?
Look at those two guys?
What two guys?
Getting out of the boat. He looks.
Yeah. .?
They don't look like the guys we took the boats from? The ones who killed Taylor?
I don't know. They were too far away then. And they're too far away now. (CONTINUED)
I think it's them.
Man, don't go gettin' paranoid on me.
I got reason to be paranoid. So do you. He gets up and starts for the food table. Calvelli contin to watch the two men. :
The men move into the clearing. It's impossible to say whether or not they are Taylor's killers.
Watching them.
Playing louder...faster. Ocarina guitar, violin, accordio Jew's harp.

Two huge four hundred pound porkers in wooden cages. Two Cajuns approach the cages. One draws a huge gutting knife and runs it across the bars. The hog squeals. The men laugh. Then each man uncoils a rope and ties a noose. The are joined by the two men from the pirogue.
He watches the conversation. He gets up. (CONTINUED)
The four Cajuns talking and laughing. It now becomes clea they are tying the ropes into hangman's nooses.
Atwater is receiving a giant plate of food. He turns to s Calvelli moving quickly towards him, bumping into people, knocking over plates on his way. Finally as Calvelli reac him.
Jesus, will you take it easy.
I'm getting out of here right now.
What for?
I don't think I want to stay for the hanging. He gestures in the direction of the cypress tree. Atwater
Two of the men are throwing the nooses over the branch of tree, and testing them for strength.
Atwater laughs.
Those are for bleeding the hogs.
You're fucking crazy. (CONT INUED)
I'm telling you...
I'm not staying to see if you're right. Before Atwater can say anything, Calvelli suddenly takes Atwater follows.

Calvelli trying to move through the crowd on the floor. Suddenly he's boxed in. A group of people with their arms locked together dance around him. They try to pull him in the dance. Calvelli panics. He punches one man, pushes another aside and races for the forest. The music stops. General confusion.
Moving across the dance floor.
No. Wait! You don't understand! Atwater runs off after Calvelli.

Running in dead panic...branches and foliage cutting at h face and arms, mud underfoot...he slows...begins walking, the carving knife in his right hand. A small glade appears before him, He enters, sees:
He smiles, gestures to Calvelli...A very innocent looking (CONTINUED)
child; the same innocent looking child that watched Longb sink into the quicksand. Calvelli approaches cautiously, still holding his knife.
I want to go home. The boy gestures Calvelli closer...closer. Then Blackbeard steps out from behind a tree. Aims his ri at Calvelli.

Can't believe it anyway...He smiles as Blackbeard fires, for him. Blackbeard fires again...Calvelli gets to him, p the knife hard into his stomach... Now Blackbeard can't believe it. Knife sticking out...onl the handle visible. He shoots Calvelli again. Again. Cur TO:
Running through the swamp; he can hear gunfire...he appro a dense thicket, moves through, comes out into the glade.

Atwater crosses to the two bodies. Calvelli sitting up ag a tree, eyes open and very dead. Blackbeard on his back, frozen into a final mask. The Cajun boy nowhere to be seen. Atwater moves near Calvelli, looks at him.
We had it made. We had it made. Sound of a Jew's harp. Atwater turns...
Standing there with his rifle...levels it...fires as Atwa dives for the ground.

The bullet slams into the log near his head, he rolls, an shot tears into the wood... He can see Blackbeard's rifle, and the knife sticking out his middle...Both out of reach...He rolls again as anothe shot tears home...Jumps up, makes a break for the trees.. another shot...
Atwater running through the swamp...running, running, run
Following the trail of army combat boots. He moves silent relentlessly...

Still running but very fatigued...SLOWING...SLOWING...SLO Lungs bursting, he bends, doubles over, gasping...Can't m another step. He kneels down, starts to untie the lace on his combat boot... cur TO:
He moves through the terrain, following the visible trail footsteps leading past

head_text.subj: A THOUSAND YEAR OLD DEAD CYPRESS

text: Huge, bleached white, petrified. Just as Mudman walks by.
His timing is perfect. The bootlace garrote has Mudman ar the neck.

Mudman pitches and spins, a wild Brahma bull, snorting an bucking, but his rider hangs on...Mudman runs backward, crushing Atwater against the great tree. Again. Again. But the garrote doesn't lessen...
Mudman's elbows are pistons driving into Atwater's sides. Mudman reaches back, grabs a handful of Atwater's hair, t to pull Atwater's skull off, but the garrote doesn't less
As the breath is choked out of him; his legs can no longe support his weight...He stands quivering...makes one fina desperate reach back...
Then to his stomach...he flops face first into the mud... Atwater still sitting on his back, squeezing...Finally Atwater's hands let go of the two pieces of wood to which the bootlace is tied...
Staggers to his feet. He takes Mudman's rifle and knife..
comes out of the swamp, in front of Atwater. Atwater backs away, he doesn't want any more...The Boy kneels next to Mudman...quietly sits there.
looking at the Boy and the dead Mudman...he turns and run still carrying Mudman's rifle.
dark water and moss covered lily pads. Atwater wades thro coming out in open marsh...up ahead he can see:
He runs for it, sprinting, just as a Helicopter comes zoo across the tree tops...Atwater climbs the slope on the ru

Running along its stone bed road, Atwater waves and chase the Chopper. Though it's gone from sight he still runs... FAINT MUSIC IS HEARD...voices singing, in Cajun French. Atwater looks around, listens, starts walking away from t levee, toward the direction of the singing...the music ge louder with each step. He stands poised, rifle ready...
Pick-up trucks and campers parked in front. Some of the vehicles attached to trailers and outboard motor-boats...
Walking toward the bar. The music is very loud. Unmistaki Cajun French.
He stops and gathers himself, wiping away the dirt and sw and blood...Lifts the rifle, bursts through the door read to fire...

Atwater's momentum carries him into the center of the roo A sign on the wall, "World's Greatest Jambalaya, World's Friendliest People". In one corner a group of Cajuns sing along to the Juke Box. The rest of the bar filled with...
in their clean fatigues. They play pool, cards, pinball, darts...Some dance with Cajun Women. One of the Guardsmen looks up as Atwater enters.
Atwater. Hey! It's Atwater! The rest of the Guardsmen look up from their tables.
Jesus, Atwater, what the hell kind of show you been putting on?
We been lookin' all over for you guys.
looks over at him. The Guardsman is at a table with Atwat four smiling Cajun girls...Their smiles more than a touch confused by his disheveled appearance.
Come on, Atwater. Have a beer. Atwater just keeps standing there and looking at them.
